newsitem.title: CHINA: China's Li vows tough stance on ethnic unrest.
newsitem.headline: China's Li vows tough stance on ethnic unrest.

text.p: Chinese Premier Li Peng vowed on Saturday to take a tough line on ethnic unrest, one of Beijing's chief security fears as it fights to keep restive Moslems and Tibetans under control in its vast border regions.

Li's pledge, in his annual speech to parliament, came a day after Chinese police reported several arrests following time-bomb attacks on buses in the Moslem-dominated far-west region of Xinjiang that killed four people and wounded more than 60.
Li's speech did not mention Tuesday's attacks, which have not been reported by China's state-controlled media.

But he said his government would "unswervingly safeguard the unity of the motherland and ethnic unity, and resolutely oppose any words or activities designed to split the country or damage ethnic unity."

Tuesday's blasts in Urumqi, the centre of Chinese control over Xinjiang and its ethnic Uighur population, were the latest examples of brewing unrest in the vast, oil-rich region bordering Central Asia.
Nobody has claimed responsibility for the attacks, but Urumqi officials believe they were planned by Uighur separatists who have mounted a campaign for an independent "East Turkestan" in the region.

China also faces sporadic outbursts of unrest in Tibet, which has been under tight security since 1959 when troops put down an anti-Chinese uprising and the region's spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, fled into exile.
Li said it was important that China "consolidate and develop" ethnic unity, which he said was already improving.
"We should value and further develop this good situation," he said.
He said China was committed to respecting religious freedom and to "helping various religions to adapt themselves to socialist society".
